content: The Fall of Tyre
The pronouncement concerning Tyre:
Wail, you ships of Tarshish,
For  is destroyed, without house  harbor;
It is reported to them from the land of Cyprus.
Be silent, you inhabitants of the coastland,
You merchants of Sidon;
Your messengers crossed the sea
And  on many waters.
The grain of the Nile, the harvest of the River was her revenue;
And she was the market of nations.
Be ashamed, Sidon,
For the sea speaks, the stronghold of the sea, saying,
“I have neither been in labor nor given birth,
I have neither brought up young men  raised virgins.”
When the report  Egypt,
They will be in anguish over the report of Tyre.
Pass over to Tarshish;
Wail, you inhabitants of the coastland.
Is this your jubilant ,
Whose origin is from antiquity,
Whose feet used to bring her to colonize distant places?
Behold, the land of the Chaldeans—this is the people  did not exist; Assyria allocated it for desert creatures—they erected their siege towers, they stripped its palaces, they made it a ruin.
Wail, you ships of Tarshish,
For your stronghold is destroyed.
Now on that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years it will happen to Tyre as  the song of the prostitute:
Take  harp, wander around the city,
You forgotten prostitute;
Pluck the strings skillfully, sing many songs,
That you may be remembered.
It will come about at the end of seventy years that the  will visit Tyre. Then she will go back to her prostitute’s wages and commit prostitution with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.

Her profit and her prostitute’s wages will be sacred to the ; it will not be stored up or hoarded, but her profit will become sufficient food and magnificent attire for those who dwell in the presence of the .
